On Monday 15 September 2003 19:23, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chris Dollin wrote:
> > On Thursday 07 August 2003 18:25, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >  > I have just built ParameterizedTestSuite, which allows you to
> >
> > automatically
> >
> >  > build a suite of tests (from test* methods), but pass parameters to
> >  > the underlying test fixture.
> >
> > I didn't see this fly by, so [now the Release Pressure has dropped on our
> > system] I'm having a go myself. It's not very general, but here's what
> > I've got/done, and a Question:
> >
> > * AbstractTestGraph is the class [subclass, eventually, of TestCase] of
> >   tests for Graph; subclasses must define getGraph() to return the Graph
> >   to be tested.
> >
> > * There are three styles of Graph, so each new implementation of Graph at
> >   the moment has to generate three new subclasses of AbstractTestGraph,
> >   one for each style of Graph for getGraph, and suite them up together.
> >   Ikky.
>
> To avoid this, pass the Graph to the graph test as a constructor. The
> graph test stores the graph in a field (as part of the fixture).

The "Ikky" applied to the original code; the revised code I described doesn't
need to do it, because the class gets passed into the suite-construction,
and it replicates the test for each style, extracting the constructor from the
graph class as you suggest.

> What I haven't solved to my satisfaction is how best to create a
> parameterized test case that runs multiple tests with the same
> parameters. If I override runTest(), then that runs only one test, which
> I don't like. I want to know how to do this without re-implementing the
> code in JUnit that invokes a test by reflection.

I gave up and re-implemented [a useful fragment of] that code. 

> > And the Question is, why are TestSuite::isPublicTestMethod and
> > TestSuite::isTestMethod *private*? Because even if I wrote a subclass
> > of TestSuite, rather than using methods in MetaTestGraph, I wouldn't
> > be able to re-use them ...
>
> There was no need to make them non-private until now, I guess. :)

There wasn't a need to make them private in the first place, surely.
